ISBN:9780262730099.subtitle: or control and communication in the animal and the machine
ISBN:9780262730099.title: Cybernetics

excerpts.text:
Cybernetics describes the application of statistical mechanics methods to communications engineering.  Its subject matter ranges from such control mechanisms as servo-mechanisms, mathematical calculators, and automatic pilots, to the nerves and brain of the human body.

This is a study of human control functions and mechanico-electrical systems designed to replace them.  As such it impinges on every branch of science.  It is the outgrowth of extensive theoretical study and experimentation by Dr. Wiener and a group of outstanding scientists -- including physiologists, psychologists, mathematicians, and electrical engineers.

table_of_contents.title: Dial-Up Mail Server for a Singe Domain

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 5
table_of_contents.pagenum: Wietse Venema says that Postfix is actually a router, one that routes messages instead of IP packets. In Postfix Anatomy, you'll get the big picture of how the Postfix innards interact.
table_of_contents.title: Anatomy of Postfix

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 7
table_of_contents.pagenum: Restrictions control SMTP communication. Understanding Restrictions explains how restrictions work.
table_of_contents.title: Understanding Restrictions

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 8
table_of_contents.pagenum: Restrictions shows you how to put them to practical use on your system.
table_of_contents.title: Restrictions

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 9
table_of_contents.pagenum: Checks do their work based on message content. Understanding *_checks explains how checks work.
table_of_contents.title: Understanding Checks

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 11
table_of_contents.pagenum: Filters delegate SMTP communication management and content control to external applications. This might be necessary if a certain task clearly lies beyond the duties on the MTA (virus filtering is one example). As with restrictions and checks, the discussion of filters breaks down into two chapters: Understanding Filters for a discussion of how filters work.
table_of_contents.title: Understanding Filters

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 12
table_of_contents.pagenum: Filters gives you something that you can actually get your hands on.
table_of_contents.title: Filters

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 13
table_of_contents.pagenum: Mail relays transport messages on behalf of other mail servers or clients. In most cases, mail relays are exposed to the Internet, while the other servers sit safely behind a firewall. In addition, you'll see how to make a smart host out of a simple mail relay.
table_of_contents.title: Mail Relays

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 14
table_of_contents.pagenum: This chapter describes the two ways that Postfix can handle mail for multiple domains. In addition, you will see how to configure Postfix to query an SQL server instead of looking at static maps.
table_of_contents.title: A Mail Server for Multiple Domains

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 15
table_of_contents.pagenum: SMTP authentication is a system for authenticating mail clients before they relay messages. Because SMTP authentication in Postfix relies on the Cyrus SASL software, Understanding SMTP Authentication shows you how to configure Cyrus SASL before you can use it with Postfix.
table_of_contents.title: SMTP Authentication Primer

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 16
table_of_contents.pagenum: Continuing the discussion of SMTP authentication, Simple Authentication and Security Layer shows you how to configure Postfix for server- and/or client-side authentication.
table_of_contents.title: SMTP Authentication

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 17
table_of_contents.pagenum: Transport Layer Security (TLS) encrypts the communication layer between Postfix and other hosts. The Postfix implementation of Transport Layer Security requires OpenSSL, so Understanding Transport Layer Security not only shows you how TLS works, but also how to prepare the required certificates.
table_of_contents.title: Understanding Transport Layer Security

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 18
table_of_contents.pagenum: This chapter shows you how to set up the Postfix server to offer encryption to other hosts and how to make the Postfix client use it when other servers offer TLS. You will also see how certificate-based relaying works.
table_of_contents.title: Transport Layer Security

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 19
table_of_contents.pagenum: This chapter explains how to configure Postfix to query an LDAP server. In doing so, you will delegate the job of local delivery to an MDA (message delivery agent) and configure a basic Courier IMAP server. In the end, you will have a complete mail system that gets user data from an OpenLDAP server.
table_of_contents.title: A Company Mail Server

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 20
table_of_contents.pagenum: Chrooting Postfix adds another barrier against intrusion. This chapter will tell you how to do that and will give you tipps how you can bring in other applications Postfix might need into the jail too.
table_of_contents.title: Running Postfix in a chroot Environment

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 21
table_of_contents.pagenum: Postfix 2.2 and 2.1 snapshots include a new feature for limiting the rate of client connections. Rate limiting is a countertactic for protecting Postfix from SMTP clients that inundate the smtpd daemon with too many connections at once. This chapter illustrates several instances where rate limiting is useful and shows you how to configure it.
table_of_contents.title: Rate Limiting

table_of_contents.label: Chapter 22
table_of_contents.pagenum: Postfix is fast out of the box, but like other packages, you can usually tune it to work even faster. Furthermore, there are situtations where Postfix may not perform as well you expected, whether it is due to hardware or software limitations on the server system or other adverse conditions such as a big influx of spam or undeliverable mail. ¶ This chapter shows you how to find and analyze the most common performance problems.
table_of_contents.title: Performance Tuning

table_of_contents.label: Appendix A
table_of_contents.pagenum: Installation contains installation instructions from source code as well as for the Debian and RedHat Linux distributions.
table_of_contents.title: Installation

table_of_contents.label: Appendix B
table_of_contents.pagenum: Having trouble with something when you try to modify a configuration? Troubleshooting Postfix gives you some advice for the most frequent gotchas, and gives some general tips for tracking down problems.
table_of_contents.title: Troubleshooting Postfix

table_of_contents.label: Appendix C
table_of_contents.pagenum: Not everyone can memorize subnets in CIDR notation and SMTP server response codes. We've put them together for you in CIDR notation and response codes.
table_of_contents.title: CIDR and SMTP Standards Reference

table_of_contents.label: Glossary
table_of_contents.title: If there's some weird technical term that you don't know, check the Glossary.

excerpts.text: IN MOST contemporary educational situations where children come into contact with computers the computer is used to put children through their paces, to provide exercises of an appropriate level of difficulty, to provide feedback, and to dispense information.

IN MOST contemporary educational situations where children come into contact with computers the computer is used to put children through their paces, to provide exercises of an appropriate level of difficulty, to provide feedback, and to dispense information.

In many schools today, the phrase “computer-aided instruction” means making the computer teach the child. One might say the computer is being used to program the child. In my vision, the child programs the computer and, in doing so, both acquires a sense of mastery over a piece of the most modern and powerful technology and establishes an intimate contact with some of the deepest ideas from science, from mathematics, and from the art of intellectual model building.
